title: Will the UK or EU trigger Article 16 of the Northern Ireland Protocol before 15 May 2022?
preds: G7 foreign ministers' meeting in Germany ending today. Liz Truss probably currently (Saturday) on her way back home. Mr Johnson is more than enough proven to be a liar: https://www.bbc.com/news/58001530 It is not happening - at least not today.

The UK AG's legal opinion raises the chance of Article 16 being triggered, but there are only two working days before 15 May. Reports suggest that a trigger could come as early as next week (i.e. 16 May onwards).

I think this FT article (https://www.ft.com/content/e984f582-4b26-45ba-b0c9-adb425147ad1)  says the UK is preparing to take unilateral action next week.  So good job to the question askers knowing this was relevant and nearly nailing the date.  And good job to all the forecasters who were certain this wouldn't happen within the timeline.

"The foreign secretary has concluded that there is little point trying to reach a Brexit deal with the European Union and will move as soon as next week to scrap large parts of the Northern Ireland protocol in British law." https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/stop-posturing-eu-tells-britain-after-threat-to-northern-ireland-protocol-mr58n23kt
Not in anyone's interest (NI, IR, EU) to do so.

Some discussion of it again in the past week, but timeline is super tight. At least from what I've read, it sounds more like a threat to put pressure on the EU to negotiate rather than an actual suggestion that the UK will suddenly pull out of an international treaty.   https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2022/apr/22/johnson-preparing-to-fix-northern-ireland-brexit-deal
Revised down to reflect closer proximity of deadline and little apparent material change in inclination to trigger.
https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/uk-eu-an-impasse-over-changes-n-ireland-protocol-2022-04-28/ still plenty of time for chest-bumping and snarling before anything actually happens, i suspect
This will cause supply chain issues Inflation is already up Need to have unity to handle Ukraine crisis

I don't think the UK or EU will trigger Article 16 because transporting goods into Northern Ireland and then transporting that into the republic of Ireland seems extra, they can just import the goods straight to the Republic of Ireland.
Zero reason for this at the moment

Sinn Fein is poised to win, while they are running re other issues, this will signal distancing from UK as they have supported a soft border. It is only 10 days between the elections and the cut off, so they will be occupied elsewhere. But Jacob Rees-Mogg seems keen to distinguish himself in his new role regardless of everything going on elsewhere and "wheels are in motion" so.... 2%
Too much going on in Europe for this risk right now.  Johnson getting publicity he needs from Ukraine effort so even though conditions exist to trigger,  they won't do it now.

There's no point in throwing a hissy-fit if no one's around to watch. The "let's cut off our nose" party in UK will wait for at least a few cameras to turn away from Putin before renewing their chest-beating over a hard border.
No chance now as attention elsewhere.
<1% so rounding to zero. With the short time span remaining it seems exceedingly unlikely
Highly unlikely with everything else that is going on.
Little reason to do this just now.
Nobody in the EU parliament has the character, charisma and courage to take such bold action.
It is unlikely that this would happen that quickly. even if it were to happen.
Distractions elsewhere suggest that this is unlikely.
The UK has been threatening to invoke Article 16 for a long time now. I'd say the real chance of this happening is <0.5%, but I'll hedge with the crowd.
Distractions elsewhere makes this less likely to happen.

Still waffling with recommendations last week that this be enacted.  Given that Johnson likes chaos,  I still stay just below the 50% mark of random toss with a slight favor towards European Unity as a weight against.
Very low probability at the moment due to the crisis in Ukraine.

If Article 16 is triggered, it would be done by the UK. It would be triggered by Tories seeking to prove they are sufficiently conservative (read: populist). Too much going on right now with Ukraine to give said politicians any light in the media. If the Tories boldly cut off their nose with a hard border, it will be sometime after the rest of the face has accepted some (small) number of Ukrainian refugees.

Current focus on European unity due to Ukraine decreases the probability that Johnson will aggravate the EU at this time.  Plus he doesn't need to publicity rebound at this point so decreasing below 50%.  The conditions still exist and Britain can still pass a law that give N Ireland access to goods in an easier manner which would then satisfy the current challenge of the Irish Sea border for the most critical goods.
I don't think the political will is there at the moment.
I actually think more are united right now due to Putin, who knows by fall or next year with short term memories though.
I really don't think it's likely, but surprises can happen.
No.  Many other priorities including Ukraine to over ride this.
With hardship in Europe this may be pressed by Britain, However these problems haven’t gotten too bad yet

Only keeping it above 0% as it is the sort of thing Boris Johnson might do to distract from yet another scandal/ major error of judgement. Otherwise doing this in the current climate would be unthinkable.
2 months seems like a short period for such actions. Also, focus seems to be somewhere now (war), and Europe will want to appear united.
England and Europe have enough problems to deal with. Won't settle the border and Euro problem till the war is resolved or later.

timeline: 2 months 
either UK (yes/no) or EU (yes/no) > 2/4 = 50% if it were to be a dice roll 
very difficult to find an outside view here. 
first mention in news 19 november 
13th january boris mentiones it 
29th january eu mentions it
it's not been triggered for 5 months, why would they now?  I count 3 possible cases in 5 months and no action Johnson unlikely to trigger article 16 because of to https://www.ft.com/content/b5603f65-ab7a-4893-b9ce-56b92d073915 Current news says it is likely that UK is going to trigger it 
I put 5

Everybody will probably be on their best behaviour for a while.  Of course, for PM BoJo his best behaviour is the governmental equivalent of a drunken brawl in a pub, but luckily the EU players are more grown-up than he and will be trying to focus on the Ukraine situation, among others.
I'm reaffirming no on this as some time has passed.

Unlikely at present, given the situation in Ukraine, any political posturing to cause friction and issues around the EU would be seen as counter productive, especially given the lack of discussion around the topic recently, could be used in political posturing but seems unlikely to come to fruition before the deadline.
I think that the Russia-Ukraine situation puts a damper on any sort of conflict in the West, however, based on what others have said, there are political motives to do so (or at least, posturing?).
Too many other things going on right now for the UK to do this
BJ wants it, overriding Truss's last comment?  Sounds like there is a chance.... https://www.msn.com/en-gb/news/uknews/uks-truss-ready-to-trigger-article-16-over-stalled-uk-eu-talks-times/ar-AAVcFdI
I have no real basis to challenge the wisdom of the crowd here. But, I'm edging higher due to a few comments from other forecasters.
Going up a bit as it's possible the tories will try to use Article 16 as a last-ditch effort to get some support before the local elections in England and Northern Ireland.
The situation in Ukraine is likely to consume much of the bandwidth for UK and EU leaders, reducing the appetite for political conflict over Article 16.
Conditions to activate already exist but Britain hasn't claimed yet.  Johnson need for  local popularity could motivate doing this specifically for food to N Ireland

It seems that threats to trigger Article 16 have been consistently happening. More to the point, Boris Johnson seems to want to reform it, just as much as he wants to trigger it. Threats to trigger Article 16 from Liz Truss have diminished over the last few days. (https://www.export.org.uk/news/598880/Truss-puts-Article-16-threats-on-hold-as-UK-and-EU-continue-to-prioritise-response-to-Ukraine-crisis.htm)
Not a priority anymore right now.

As with many things concerning this issue, this seems very unlikely, should however not be considered impossible. Should the UK see any advantage in staggering trade with the EU (esp. with France) to renegotiate or resolve conflicts with the EU, this could happen. However, the reason why the EU was such a good "deal" for the UK initially (and always has been, trade wise at least) is access to the single market and the ease of access which is to some extent held up by the current agreement between the parties. Thus, even under current tensions, such a move would be deeply unnecessary and unbeneficial for all involved.
-15, dropping way down from my original survey forecast based on the crowd.

I think over the next couple months the Russian invasion will increase unity and put on hold these kinds of squabbles. Recent articles suggest it's on hold for the time being so I don't see it happening until things calm down. Leaving 20% chance though because it sounded like it was in the works until invasion happened.

Initial forecast 3/17: I don't know a lot about this and have limited time right now to research more.  However, it appears that this has been considered by Johnson yet is on-hold due to Russia's war on Ukraine.  I think it would be fairly unlikely that this would happen until that situation is more stable.
I know next to nothing about this, so I'm following the crowd but anticipate the crowd is being weighed down by too many unrealistic zeros
Not much information to forecast with but it does seem to be something the UK is actively considering.

Plenty of other things on everyone’s mind at the moment, and another complication like this is something no one wants.  Dealing with this problem can be postponed for a while. But have to keep a 1pc because weird things could happen!

I think right now with the Ukrainian conflict all parties involved have bigger concerns and expect talks to be delayed. It seems unimaginable this would be high enough on anyones priorities at the moments to trigger the Article before May 15th. Leaving 1% margin of error for a quick resolution to the Ukrainian conflict, or some black swan event driving a wedge further between the UK and the EU raising the priority of this. But that seems incredibly unlikely.

The imminent triggering of Article 16 seems to have been discussed in the press fairly frequently in the past few months (see Nov 2021 [1]  Jan 2022 [2]).  However, Putin's attack on Ukraine seem to have postponed those discussions for now:  "Boris Johnson is unlikely to trigger Article 16 proceedings against the EU over the controversial Northern Ireland protocol ahead of May’s Stormont elections due to the war in Ukraine.," [3]  (Stormont elections scheduled for 5 May 2022) [4] [1] https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2021/nov/05/will-the-uk-trigger-article-16-and-what-will-happen-if-it-does
[2] https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/uk-still-ready-trigger-article-16-eu-nireland-row-truss-says-2022-01-08/
[3] https://www.ft.com/content/b5603f65-ab7a-4893-b9ce-56b92d073915
[4] https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2022_Northern_Ireland_Assembly_election
“Raoul Ruparel, who worked as a senior Brexit advisor to Thersa May says he thinks this sort of maximalist approach to article 16 is likely”
Highly unlikely, as there are more pressing matters for the attention of decision makers.
Tories say "YES PULL THE TRIGGER NOW DO IT NOW". All who are sane disagree. Plus, Johnson is against it so I'm giving it a hard pass.
Little political will for this now if public comments from officials are any indication.
Highly unlikely given Ukraine situation, during which UK/EU spats more likely to be set aside.
My initial forecast was not aggressive enough
I can't really see this happening by May 15 given the conflict with Russia.
There did seem to be political appetite for it prior to the Ukraine situation and a lot can change in 2 months
There will be virtually no appetite for a trade war in the current situation in Europe
